newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia is dying, doctors warn.
newsitem.headline: Russia is dying, doctors warn.

text.p: Russia is dying, its doctors said on Saturday, warning that the population was shrinking at a rate never before seen in peacetime and accusing the government of failing in its legal duty to provide health care.
"Russia is losing its main state asset -- its citizens," the Russian Pirogov Congress of Physicians said in a resolution after a three-day meeting of over 1,700 leading doctors.
The resolution, quoted by Interfax news agency, decried the "unprecedented peacetime decline in the Russian population."

State statistics show the country is losing about a million of its 150 million people every year, as the death rate outstrips the birth rate by 1.6 times. A third of those dying are still of working age, the doctors noted.
Economic hardships since the collapse of the Soviet Union have damaged Russians' health and state medical care for ordinary people has declined.
Men in particular, who also suffer from high levels of alcoholism, have seen their average life expectancy sink to 58, at least 15 years less than men in west Europe.
The doctors sent a letter to Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin arguing that the government was in breach of its constitutional obligation to provide free health care.
They resolved to take the issue to the state prosecutor and Constitutional Court.
